conclusion: The problem involves analyzing the motion of a missile launched vertically from a height of 20000 meters, accelerating upward due to thrust, and then following a curved trajectory influenced by the angle θ of the jet direction.
The image shows a missile launched vertically from the ground at an altitude of 20000 meters, following a curved trajectory downward to hit an enemy aircraft flying horizontally.

The missile's rocket engine expels gas vertically downward initially, causing it to accelerate uniformly upward with an acceleration of 10g until it reaches an altitude of 5000 meters. The thrust remains constant, and air resistance is negligible.
The jet direction changes to an angle θ with the vertical direction (cos θ = 1/11), slanting downward to the right, causing the missile to follow a curved trajectory.

premise: The missile accelerates upward with an acceleration of 10g (100 m/s²) until it reaches an altitude of 5000 meters.
conclusion: The vertical acceleration during the initial phase is 100 m/s².

conclusion: The vertical velocity at the point where the missile reaches 5000 meters is v_y = 100 × t.

conclusion: The time to reach 5000 meters is t = 10 seconds.
